Journal.Title: The Science of the total environment

Article.ArticleTitle: Nitrogenous air pollutants and ozone exposure in the central Sierra Nevada and White Mountains of California - Distribution and evaluation of ecological risks.

AbstractText: Ammonia (NH<sub>3</sub>), nitric oxide (NO), nitrogen dioxide (NO<sub>2</sub>), nitric acid (HNO<sub>3</sub>), and ozone (O<sub>3</sub>) were measured in summers of 2012 and 2013 with passive samplers. Nine monitoring sites were on W-E transect (511 to 3490 m) across central Sierra Nevada Mountains (SNM), and five sites on elevational gradient (1237 to 4346 m) in White Mountains (WM) of California. Levels of pollutants were similar in 2012 and 2013 in all sites. NH<sub>3</sub>, NO<sub>2</sub>, and HNO<sub>3</sub> were highest near highly polluted Central Valley of California (CVC): maximum summer season means 7.8 μg m<sup>-3</sup>, 3.0 ppb, and 3.0 μg m<sup>-3</sup>, respectively. Regional background for NH<sub>3</sub>, NO<sub>2</sub>, and HNO<sub>3</sub> in SNM occurred >20 km from CVC and >1500 m with seasonal averages: 2.1-4.8 μg m<sup>-3</sup>; 0.8-1.7 ppb; 1.0-1.8 μg m<sup>-3</sup>, respectively, during two seasons. Levels of NH<sub>3</sub>, NO<sub>2</sub>, and HNO<sub>3</sub> in WM remote locations were similar: 1.2-3.3 μg m<sup>-3</sup>, 0.6-1.1 ppb, and 1.0-1.3 μg m<sup>-3</sup>, respectively. Seasonal mean O<sub>3</sub> (38-60 ppb) in SNM did not change with distance from CVC nor elevation. In WM, O<sub>3</sub> and NO mixing ratios were 41-61 ppb and 2.3-4.1 ppb, respectively, increasing with elevation. Even the lowest NH<sub>3</sub> concentrations determined in this study were higher than NH<sub>3</sub> continental background. This fact, as well as high values of N<sub>reduced</sub>/N<sub>oxidized</sub> near CVC of 1.9 in 2012 and 2.0 in 2013, decreasing with distance to 0.7 in 2012 and 0.8 in 2013, show importance of NH<sub>3</sub> emissions from CVC as a contributor to N deposition and ecological impacts in SNM. The phytotoxic O<sub>3</sub> indices, AOT40 and W126, for selected sites on SNM and WM transects, showed high potential for negative O<sub>3</sub> impacts on vegetation, including forest trees. CAPSULE: Elevated NH<sub>3</sub>, NO<sub>2</sub>, and HNO<sub>3</sub> on the western slopes of the Sierra Nevada Mountains (SNM) near the Central Valley of California (CVC) decreased with distance from CVC and elevation to regional background levels also recorded at high elevation sites of the White Mountains (WM).
